data:
{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3364834,"name":"Ben","username":"Bzc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bzc/{size}/213635_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T04:34:16.540Z","cooked":"

The entire pit was designed by two sophomores on our team, Stella and Eesha. They wrote this post together but due to CDs new account restrictions, I am posting this on behalf of them.

Some background

Our old pit consisted of a toolchest, shelves, and several sets of drawers that we’d haul to competitions… not the most efficient or aesthetically appealing design, but it got the job done until this year, when we finally decided we needed a proper pit. This post goes into the details of the much-needed upgrade we made this year, and the build process we went through to design and build our new Superpit.

Before:

Old Pit

After:

Superpit 2024!!

The Superpit is far from an original Glitch 2.0 design; it’s been done by many different teams, in many different ways. Hightide (FRC 4414) in particular inspired our design. However, their cases wouldn’t have worked for our team for the following reasons:

  1. Cost. For a lot of smaller teams, including us, coming up with enough money to have custom cases made for us from a company is a challenge. That’s why we made our cases ourselves and with different materials: to reduce cost.

  2. Transportation. If you take a look at Hightide’s pit, they’ve got two large cases and one in the corner. With the amount of tools and other equipment that we’re storing in our team’s pit, if we’d done two larger cases, they would have each easily weighed over 500 lbs each. That’s why we split our cases into six smaller ones, because we don’t have the means to transport anything that large or that heavy.

OK. Time to get into it. I encourage you to go to our website and check out the dimensions!

Priorities for the pit

  1. Store everything you could possibly need, as well as backups, and backups for the backups

  2. Organize everything in an easy-to-find way, to (hopefully) eliminate that between-matches panic when you can’t find the tool you need.

  3. Everything should be easily transportable.

  4. Well-lit and easy access to electricity.

  5. Lots of workspace.

How the cases work

Each case is made of three sections: the bottom, top and lid. The bottom and top are joined by a hinge along the front, allowing the top to swing down within the L-shape of the bottom when we want to fold it up. The lid is completely removable from the other parts of the case. It latches on to the top of the case when it’s unfolded, then is removed and reattached to the front of the case when closed. The folding mechanism is shown here:

Pit Folding

We have hybrid tongue and groove channels along the parts of the case that meet up when folded, ensuring that there’s a tight seal. Latches hold the cases shut, and there’s handles embedded in the wood for easy transportation. Each case is also mounted on casters, so that they can be wheeled around.

Latch and Handle

CAD and Design

Since we built these cases ourselves rather than ordering them from a professional, we cadded everything first. We already knew roughly what we wanted to store in each case, so that gave us pretty good dimensions as to how big each case had to be, while still fitting in the 9x9 pit area. Most of the CAD time consisted of us tweaking dimensions slightly to make sure that we could maximize storage while still allowing for the cases to fold easily. For this pit we used ¾ inch-thick wood for the bases of each case as well as the work surfaces, and ⅜ inch-thick wood for the sides and top. We cadded each individual piece of wood as a separate component and assembled them together in Fusion 360 last, since we wanted to cut the pieces on a CNC machine and needed each piece separately in order to easily do that. That made the process for the basic shape take a little bit longer, but overall it wasn’t too hard to get the general wood structure done.

You can see CAD models and dimensions on our website GLITCH PIT | Glitch8727.

To reinforce the corners, we added aluminum angles that we would insert into the inner and outer corners of each case. These were cheap, simple angles (nothing special) that you could find at Lowes or Home Depot.

After the general structure was finished, we cut holes for the latches and handles. Handles were embedded into the front and back of each case. The latches consisted of two parts, one on each piece you want to join together. We had to cut some of the angles to make these work.

Pit CAD

Fabrication

After finishing the CAD, we started the actual physical build. As I mentioned before, the wood was cut on a CNC (Shopbot 4x8) machine. We CADded models of the plywood we were using (4 feet by 8 feet, ¾ and ⅜ inch thick), then arranged our pieces on top of the wood in the way that best conserved wood. We used Fusion 360’s manufacturing interface to create toolpaths that could then be transferred to the CNC machine.

Tool Paths

Cutting was just a matter of running the toolpaths, but this took several days as we had to cut a LOT of wood. Once everything was cut, we painted everything (black), and assembled.

CNC

Cost

Overall the pit assembly priced out at around $7,000. That’s still a very steep sum, so to stifle it, we reached out to sponsors and student’s families looking for donations, both material and monetary. The call was answered, and because of all these people’s generosity, we were able to cut down the out-of-pocket cost to around $3,000. You can see the breakdown of the parts we ordered on our website GLITCH PIT | Glitch8727; there were some parts that we already had on hand, such as the boxes for parts, which aren’t included in the cost breakdown.

You can find our pit at Worlds in Houston this week in the Curie division (pit D04) if you’d like to check it out in person! We hope your team finds this useful!

This is some really phenomenal work. Weight / transportation difficulty was one of the major reasons why we haven’t built a superpit yet. Also, this makes storing the cases easier if you don’t have that much uninterrupted space in the lab.

I’ll probably work on moving the design over to Onshape for the next few hours so I can play around with it…thanks so much for releasing CAD.

We’ve killed a lot of casters on our various pit carts and toolchests, is that something you are worried about here? Do you have a specific brand you reccomend?

That’s awesome!

Q: does your team own a 4x8 CNC? That’s pretty large for more robot-related tasks. How much use do you get out of it?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2024-04-18T10:33:59.028Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":969,"readers_count":968,"score":203.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463216,"topic_slug":"glitch-2-0-budget-superpit","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/glitch-2-0-budget-superpit/463216/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3364913,"name":"","username":"Ugydukin","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T11:52:30.058Z","cooked":"

Since we are at a high school, we use the cnc in our schools wood shop, since the school hasn’t used it in a while, and we got it back up and working for this year. We’ve used it this year to cut our pit material and to try and make our patterned hole aluminum tubing.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2024-04-18T11:52:30.058Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":897,"readers_count":896,"score":179.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":463216,"topic_slug":"glitch-2-0-budget-superpit","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65614,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ugydukin"},"post_url":"/t/glitch-2-0-budget-superpit/463216/6","custom_user_title":"ugydukin","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3364915,"name":"","username":"Eeshan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/f4b2a3/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T11:53:11.708Z","cooked":"

Yes we have a 4x8 CNC at our high school. The pit was the biggest project that we’ve used it for, but we do utilize it for larger robot parts made of polycarb (like the side of our shooter this year).

(Aforementioned Glitch 2.0 pit codesigner)

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2024-04-18T16:50:09.005Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":849,"readers_count":848,"score":174.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463216,"topic_slug":"glitch-2-0-budget-superpit","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65621,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8727 Glitch 2.0"},"post_url":"/t/glitch-2-0-budget-superpit/463216/7","custom_user_title":"8727 Glitch 2.0","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3364949,"name":"","username":"vensy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/439d5e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T13:01:45.599Z","cooked":"

This is absolutely amazing - I had never thought of splitting the boxes up into multiple parts to make it easier, this is an amazing idea! Three questions:
How do you guys wire all of the boxes with electricity to power lights, etc?
What’s going on in your ‘corner’: storage, black hole of stuff?
do the sides of the inner boxes interfere with your workspace-like the inner walls that end up in the middle of your working area?
This is a really great design, and congrats to the sophomores for taking on a project like this - keep up the good work!

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2024-04-18T13:01:45.599Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":782,"readers_count":781,"score":241.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":463216,"topic_slug":"glitch-2-0-budget-superpit","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59038,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/glitch-2-0-budget-superpit/463216/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3365103,"name":"Stella","username":"StellaRi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stellari/{size}/218143_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T16:53:19.379Z","cooked":"

Thank you for the kind words!
For electricity, we have holes cut in the backs of the cases to run extension cords through. Then there’s holes in the back corners of the workspaces and shelves to run cords up to the LEDs.
The corner case is more for spacing than anything- we can move it back and forth to accommodate for varying pit sizes, 8x8, 9x9, 10x10, etc. If you visit our pit in person you’ll see we haven’t actually assembled it currently, and that space between the sides of the pit is where we stick backpacks, flags, mascot costume, all that good stuff. We plan to use the space under the workspace for all of those things once the case is assembled, and then we’ll also have more room for anything we want to put on top of that workspace.
Walls between the smaller cases do sometimes interfere with workspace. We generally use the smaller workspaces for things like programming laptops, open boxes of tools/parts, or smaller repairs. We use the workspace on the large toolchest, or the robot cart itself, for things that require more space.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2024-04-18T18:02:10.183Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":744,"readers_count":743,"score":208.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463216,"topic_slug":"glitch-2-0-budget-superpit","display_username":"Stella","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":59038,"username":"vensy","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/439d5e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64751,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8727 CAD Alum"},"post_url":"/t/glitch-2-0-budget-superpit/463216/9","custom_user_title":"8727 CAD Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3365114,"name":"Matthew K","username":"superdude311","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/superdude311/{size}/230653_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T17:10:11.940Z","cooked":"

How much cheaper is this over a conventional superpit? I can see the super pit structure is about $3800, but I can’t find a figure on the road cases.

Last summer when I asked for a quote for the 4414 cases, the total price for all the cases was around $6,900.

Funnily enough, the CNC operating experience (and CAD training) that the pit project offered weren’t the primary goal but were one of the project’s best effects on our team. The dozen-plus students involved in the design and fabrication of the pit were almost entirely new to FRC and have since become vital team members in robot CAD and prototyping.

The financial impact of a super pit was arguably the primary factor in our decision to DIY. The total cost to the team was around $3,000 by the time the pit was finished, substantially below the cost of all the pit’s components without donations and the more prebuilt alternatives. Our team comes from a small(ish) city in Western North Carolina where corporate sponsorships for FRC teams aren’t as plentiful (mainly due to a lack of tech/highly STEM-based businesses). However, the pit project allowed us to reach many new sponsors by accepting in-kind donations of materials we wouldn’t have ever used on a robot (plywood in substantial quantities, long runs of aluminum L channel, etc.). For other teams looking at expanding their pits in the future, I’d highly recommend reaching out to local lumber companies, department stores, and even aluminum distributors to see what you could get donated (it might make DIY a very affordable option).

You addressed one of my biggest concerns with the showcases by making smaller ones. The weight to safely move them has always been a big concern to me, in addition to portability.
I am “Team Milwaukee Packout” for my team because of our needs but this would be a close second for me.

Many hats"},"post_url":"/t/glitch-2-0-budget-superpit/463216/17","custom_user_title":"2141 & 21579. Many hats","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3366197,"name":"Alex Boniske","username":"413X","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/4/71c47a/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T03:53:32.841Z","cooked":"

We use a generic U-Haul trailer that we rent before each competition. Because the pit comes in multiple cases with casters, its total weight is more evenly distributed and can be easily supported in an ordinary rented trailer. The splitting up of the cases also makes transport relatively simple since our final assembly was designed with the measured space inside a U-Haul specifically in mind.

It is important to note that not all U-Hauls are the same, however. We found out that some have slightly lower ceilings the hard way and ended up putting a case on its back for transport to our first competition. Now, we make sure to call far ahead to our local franchise to reserve the specific trailer we planned for (a process that sometimes involves them choosing to mark it as “broken” so that it isn’t rented out on accident).

How do you get the cases on/off the U-Haul? Are they light enough for a 2-person lift?

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T04:26:20.662Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":476,"readers_count":475,"score":115.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":463216,"topic_slug":"glitch-2-0-budget-superpit","display_username":"Marcus Kauffman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":56888,"username":"413X","name":"Alex Boniske","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/4/71c47a/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55750,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2141 & 21579. Many hats"},"post_url":"/t/glitch-2-0-budget-superpit/463216/19","custom_user_title":"2141 & 21579. Many hats","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3366251,"name":"Alex Boniske","username":"413X","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/4/71c47a/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T04:48:13.506Z","cooked":"

Some of our smaller cases are light enough to be lifted by a few people (as was needed to maneuver them onto their sides during that first trip), but we almost always rely on a set of two wooden ramps to maneuver them on and off the U-Haul. From there they are light enough to be rolled easily by one to two people. In general though, I’d caution against trying to do a 2-person lift due to the weight and risk of tipping (it would probably be fine for the smaller non-tool chest or battery cases, but simple ramps are much easier and faster than lifting).
